title-group.article-title: Sliding mode control-based active power control for wind farm with variable speed wind generation system

abstract.p: Active power control in wind farm, implemented with hierarchical structure (including the central wind farm active power control system and the control system of variable speed wind generation system), has significantly improved the wind-farm-generated power. However, the interaction between the control system of variable speed wind generation system and the central wind farm active power control system has not been considered in the control system design of both sides. The wind generation system with active power control in wind farm, as a high-order nonlinear large-scale system, will not only autonomous operating with maximum power capture, but also being demanded to regulate power output according to the power set points ordered by the central wind farm active power control system. Therefore, robust active power control of wind farm is clearly necessary. In this article, sliding mode is used to design the active power control system for wind farm, which makes the output power of wind farm track the active power order from the power grid operator asymptotically. Particularly, the control system of the variable speed wind generation system is designed with cascaded structure: the input of the internal rotational speed control loop of the wind generation system is controlled by the external power loop which tracks the specified power set point. Then, based on the dynamic model of wind farm, the central wind farm active power control system is designed to control the total output power of wind farm by using the sliding mode control method. Furthermore, in order to ensure the given power set point is within the regulation capability of the wind generation system, the proportional distribution strategy is utilized to specify the power set point according to the available output power of each wind generation system, which is quantified by ultra-short term power prediction model. The proposed approach is illustrated by implementing it to the active power control of a wind-farm model in simulation. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms the method based on proportional-integral control.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With increasing penetration of wind power into the power grid, active power control for wind farm has been proposed to reduce the adverse effect of fluctuated wind-farm-generated power on power grid's stability and security. Recently, the wind farm active power control are designed with hierarchical structure,1–4 including the central wind farm active power control system and the control system of variable speed wind generation system (VS-WGS).

The control objective of the central wind farm active power control system is to regulate output power of the entire wind farm delivered to the power grid in a centralized way. The central wind farm active power control system includes: (i) an active power controller that makes the output power of the wind farm track the set point ordered by power system operator, (ii) and an active power distribution block that specifies the set points for all VS-WGSs according to their regulation ability and the power reference for the whole wind farm determined by the active power controller. The major part of existing researches in the central wind farm active power control system have focused on active power distribution, as demonstrated in de Almeida et al.,5 Moyano and Lopes,6 Soleimanzadeh and Wisniewski,7 Madjidian et al.8 Although these optimal methods developed for active power distribution enhance the active power tracking performance of the entire wind farm, proportional-integral (PI) control method has commonly been adopted in the active power controller due to their simple control structure, ease of design, and inexpensive cost.

On the other hand, the control objective of VS-WGS control system is to control the power output of the VS-WGS at the power reference. The power reference is the maximum power without exceeding the rated power when the VS-WGS could deliver all the available energy to the power grid, whereas the power set point ordered by the central wind farm active power control system. The great amount of recent research efforts on the control of VS-WGS are based on maximizing the energy capture for a wide range of wind speeds, without exceeding the rated power.9–15 However, as commented before, the VS-WGSs are today demanded to regulate power outputs according to the power set points ordered by the central wind farm active power control system, which are defined considering the regulation capability of the VS-WGS and the power requirement of the power grid. The previous works have present three control strategies for VS-WGS when regulating the active power output of the VS-WGS to a set point ordered by the central wind farm active power control system,1,4,5,16 where the a comparative study of these control strategies has performed by means of simulation in Fernandez et al.17 As for the control method used in these works, PI control method is adopted.

Critical challenges, however, exist that have not yet been addressed satisfactorily in current wind farm active power control. One of the main limits is that the active power control is still very conservative because of PI control method based active power controller in the central wind farm active power control system. The PI controller, which deals with the steady state model around certain operating points, fails to provide acceptable performance presence of nonlinearity, high frequency disturbances and plant parameters uncertainty. Considering that the nonlinearity inherent of VS-WGS, fluctuated wind speed, and bad operating conditions of wind farm make the PI control method inefficient, the design of nonlinear and robust active power controller is needed to deal with these problems. Another major issue is that the active power control method for individual VS-WGS when the available energy can not be entirely delivered to the power grid has not always studied in previous works. Thus, these standing challenges in active power control of wind farm motivate this work.

Take into account of the stochastic operating conditions and the inevitable uncertainties inherent in the VS-WGS, nonlinear and robust control method (such as fuzzy logic control,12 neural network control,13 adaptive control,14 etc.) have been introduced to design VS-WGS control system for maximum power capture for a wide range of wind speeds without exceeding the rated power when the available energy can be entirely delivered to the grid. Among them, sliding mode control has proved to be especially appropriate for VS-WGS control, owing to the easy implementation, fast responses, satisfactory performance over a wide range of operating conditions, and strong robustness with respect to external disturbance (electrical, mechanical and wind) and uncertainties of VS-WGS (parameter, unmodeled dynamics, etc.).15

In this article, we propose an approach based on the sliding mode control technique to the active power control of wind farm. First, sliding mode control method is introduced to design the control system of VS-WGS, aiming to make the output power of wind farm track the set point specified by the central wind farm controller. Particularly, the control system of VS-WGS adopts cascade structure consisting of two control loops in which the input of the internal control loop is deduced from external control loop, and the external control loop controls the active power to track the set point. Secondly, based on the active power tracking dynamic model of individual VS-WGS, the model of wind farm is built. Finally, the central wind farm active power control system is designed with sliding mode control method based active power controller and proportional active power distribution method. The proposed approach is illustrated by implementing to a wind farm consisting of 3 VS-WGSs in simulation. The simulation results compared to the operation results acquired in the wind farm where the conventional PI method was applied, the use of the proposed technique led to the relative active power tracking error to be significantly reduced, especially when the ramp changes appear in the active power set point ordered by power system operator.

sec.title: Sliding mode control-based active power control for wind farm
Overview of active power control of wind farm
sec.p:
In this section, the proposed active power control approach based on sliding mode control method is presented. We start with briefly describing the active power control system of wind farm. The active power control (APC) system of wind farm is schematically depicted in Figures 1 and 2. The main objective of the APC system is to adjust the power output of the entire wind farm at the common coupling point (PCC), PWF, to track the set point ordered by power system operator, PrefWF, asymptotically. Figure 1.
Active power control for wind farm.
Figure 2.
Active power control for wind generation system.

As shown in Figure 1, the active power reference for the whole wind farm, PuWF, is determined by the block of ‘Active Power Controller’ according to the wind farm power tracking error εP. Then, the active power reference for the whole wind farm determines the power set point command to each wind generation system, Prefi, based on proportional distribution strategy according to the available active power, Pavaili (achieved in the ‘Active Power Distribution’ block in Figure 1). The available active power of each individual wind generation system is obtained from an ultra-short-term power prediction model with the measured wind speed, Vi, which has been implemented in the previous work.18

As shown in Figure 2, the desired active power set point for each wind generation system Prefi, is utilized to obtain the power tracking error of the external power loop, ɛPi, along with the actual power of wind generation system, Pi. Then, the reference rotational speed to the internal rotational speed loop, wri, is obtained from the block of ‘External Control Loop’. Using the rotational speed control method, the generator torque, Tgi, controls the rotational speed of the wind generation system to track its reference value asymptotically.

sec.title: Overview of sliding mode control
sec.p: With the character of the easy implementation, fast responses, satisfactory performance over a wide range of operating conditions, and strong robustness with respect to external disturbance and modeling inaccuracies, sliding mode control for nonlinear systems have been widely investigated.

Consider a nonlinear system of the form:20 (11)x(n)(t)=f(x,t)+u(t)+d(t) where x=[x1,x2,…,xn]T=[x,x·,…,x(n-1)]T is state variable space, u(t) is the control variable, d(t) is the bounded external disturbance (|d(t)| ≤ D), and f(x, t) is a bounded nonlinear function related to the state and the time.
Considering the modeling inaccuracies (12)f(x,t)=f¯(x,t)+Δf(x,t) where Δ f(x, t) is the uncertain part of f(x, t) with the bound of F (|Δ f(x, t)| ≤ D).
Let xd=[xd,x·d,…,xd(n-1)]T be the reference trajectory, then the tracking error vector e can be qualified as (13)e=x-xd=[e,e·,…,e(n-1)]T

sec.title: Control system design for variable speed wind generation system
sec.p: In this section, sliding mode control method is implemented to design the active power control for the variable speed wind generation system. The cascade-control structure is introduced to design the active power control for variable speed wind generation system. As shown in Figure 2, there are two control loops, including the internal rotational speed control loop and external power control loop. In the internal rotational speed control loop, generator torque is designed as the control input to ensure that the rotational speed tracks its desired value asymptotically. The desired rotational speed is specified from the external power controller, which is designed by using sliding mode control method to achieve asymptotic power reference tracking.

(i) According to the sliding mode control method, the dynamic of rotational speed tracking error ɛwi of wind generation system i is chosen as (23)ɛ·wi=-aiɛwi-bisgn(ɛwi) where (24)ɛwi=wrefi-wri, ai > 0, and bi > 0.
Then, combing with equation (9), the control input generator toque can be obtained as (25)Tgi=Tri-Kiwri-aiJiɛwi-biJisgn(ɛwi)-Jiw·refi=Tri-(Ki-aiJi)wri-biJisgn(ɛwi)-Jimi where (26)mi=aiwrefi+w·refi.

To avoid the discontinuity of the control law introduced by the function of sgn(•), we use the function [sgn(s)]a to approximate sgn(s),22 (27)[sgn(s)]a={sgn(s),s≥π2ksin(ks),s≤π2k and its first derivative can be expressed by (28)[sgn(s)·]a={sgn(s), s≥π2kks·cos(ks), ▵s≤π2k}.

Then, the dynamic of the closed internal rotational speed loop can be obtained as (30)w·ri=-aiwri+mi+biJi[sgn(ɛwi)]a.

sec.p: In this section, based on the dynamic model of the wind farm, the central wind farm controller, as shown in Figure 1, is designed to ensure that the power generated from the wind farm can track the desired power specified by the power system operator asymptotically.
Based on sliding mode control methods, the dynamic of power tracking error εP of wind farm is chosen as (38)ɛ·P=-eɛP-fsgn(ɛP) where (39)ɛP=PrefWF-PWF, e > 0, and f > 0.

statement.p: Considering the system as shown in equations (9) and (10), and equation (37), the control law for central wind farm (as shown in equation (44)), with the external power controller (as shown in equation (35)) and the internal rotational speed controller (as shown in equation (29)) in each wind generation system, will render the closed-loop system asymptotically stabilize at a desired power demand from the power system operator (Proof: see the Appendix).

sec.title: Simulation and analysis
sec.p:
In this section, we illustrate the sliding mode control-based active power control method by applying it in simulation to the active power control model of a wind farm. The wind farm of 650KW*3 power generation capability consists of 3 variable speed wind generation systems with the same parameter and controller configuration, as shown in Table 1. The objective of the simulation is to demonstrate that the output of the wind farm can asymptotically track the desired power of the power system by using the proposed active power control technique, at the same time, each wind generation system can also achieve the power reference tracking. Table 1.
The parameters of the 650 kW variable speed wind generation system.
Parameter Value
Number of blades 3
Rotor radius (r) 21.65 m
Rated power (Prated) 650 kW
Equivalent inertia of the rotor (Jr) 3.25 × 105 kg·m2
Equivalent inertia of the generator (Jg) 34.4 kg·m2
Gear ratio (N) 43.165

To evaluated the efficiency of the proposed control method for active power control to meet the power requirement of the power system, we conducted a comparative study between the proposed active power control method and the PI control method commonly used in the wind-farm industry.1 The desired output for the wind farm given by the power operator system was a stair-wise signal as shown in Figure 5, where the power levels were set at 1400, 1430, 1520, 1430, and 1400 kW, with transitions occurring at 150, 250, 650, and 750 s, respectively. Such an output power demand trajectory comprising a wide variety of desired output power requirements from unchanging, rising to reclining was typical in daily operation of the modeled wind farm. The 3 variable speed wind generation systems operated at different wind region are shown in Figure 4. With the measured wind speed, the available output power of each wind generation system was qualified based on the ultra-short-term wind power prediction model.18 Figure 4.
The wind speed.
Figure 5.
Comparison of the wind farm output power obtained by using the proposed active power control method to that obtained by using the propor tional-integral (PI) method.

The output of the wind farm obtained by using the proposed active power control technique is compared with that obtained by using the PI control method based central wind farm controller in Figure 5. As shown in Figure 5(a), the output of the wind farm by using the proposed control method tracked the desired active power asymptomatically, while the output of the wind farm by using the PI control method can not follow the desired active power when it changed (as shown in Figure 5(b)). Moreover, as shown in Figure 6(a), the desired active power tracking error obtained by using the proposed control method (with the mean relative error of 0.27%) was smaller than that obtained by using the PI control method (with the mean relative error of 0.67%), which is demonstrated in Figure 6(b). Figure 6.
Comparison of the desired active power tracking error obtained by using the proposed active power control method to that obtained by using the PI method.

To demonstrate the power tracking performance of the individual VS-WGS, the simulation results (including the available power, power reference, actual output power) of each VS-WGS were analyzed. The available power, actual output power and the power reference of VS-WGS 1 are shown in Figure 7. As shown in Figure 7, the power reference for the VS-WGS1 was specified by the sliding mode control-based central wind farm active power control system according to its available power and the set point of wind farm order by power system operator. By using the sliding mode control based active power control method for VS-WGS, the actual output power of VS-WGS1 tracked its power reference closely. The available power, actual output power and the power reference of VS-WGS 2 are shown in Figure 8, while the available power, actual output power and the power reference of VS-WGS 3 are shown in Figure 9. As shown in Figures 7, 8, and 9, the output power of the 3 wind generation systems tracked the power set point quite closely, where the power set point were not exceed their regulation ability. Figure 7.
The available power, the power reference, and the actual output power of wind generation system 1.
Figure 8.
The available power, the power reference, and the actual output power of wind generation system 2.
Figure 9.
The available power, the power reference, and the actual output power of wind generation system 3.

In order to evaluate the performance of the proposed sliding mode control-based active power control for wind farm when the different type of desired power output demand is needed to meet, the desired output for the wind farm given by the power operator system was a sinusoidal signal as shown in Figure 10(a). As shown in Figure 10(b), the active power output of the wind farm by using the proposed control method tracked the sinusoidal type desired power output well. Figure 10.
Comparison of the wind farm output power obtained by using the proposed active power control method to the sinusoidal type desired output.
Therefore, the simulation results demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed active power control method in active power control of wind farm.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article presented an active power control method for wind farm based on sliding mode control method. The active power control system with cascaded structure was designed for the variable speed wind generation system to track the specified power set point asymptotically and ensure the closed system stable. Based on the active power tracking model of variable wind generation system, the model of wind farm was built. Then, the central wind farm active power control system was designed with sliding mode control method based active power controller and proportional active power distribution method. The proposed technique has been implemented to a wind farm model consisting of 3 variable speed wind generation systems in simulation. The simulation results demonstrated that by using the proposed method the output power of wind farm outperformed the PI method (the mean relative active power tracking error by using the proposed control method was reduced almost three times from 0.67% to 0.27%), especially when the changes appeared in desired power. In addition, with different type active power demand order by power system operator, the efficiency of the proposed active power control method was also verified in this article.
